 Thank you for this debate. I have been learning a good deal of interesting things which I wouldn't have know or cared about before. This reply is based on an excellent article on the purpose and value of the electoral college. (if you want to look at it, its here, quite thorough and very compelling: http://www.fec.gov/pdf/eleccoll.pdf)
 
 First of all, it should be noted that any candidate with a substantial majority is virtually guaranteed to win. When the race is close - and this is the beautiful part - the candidate with the greatest distribution of support is favoured. George Bush won 2,434 counties, Gore won only 677. The effect is to give individual states more power in choosing the President than they would in a popular vote. From the article I was reading: "...the winning candidate must demonstrate both a sufficient popular support to govern as well as a sufficient distribution of that support to govern."
 
 I think it's important to look at the information I posted earlier again:
 
 
Looking at an electoral map, with George Bush's states in red and Al Gore's in blue, the bulk of the U.S. is red. 
 (from www.boundless.org)
 
 Without the electoral college, this particular Presidential campaign would have been taken by Gore - whose support was concentrated in comparatively few states. The elections would be determined by the heavily populated cities on the coasts, and by a few big cities scattered elsewhere. The rural population would recieve little to no consideration.
 
 While small groups in Florida will be very important in the '04 election, this will change over time - and also gives greater representation to minorities. However, without the electoral college, the rural population would be permanently ignored.
